interestingcomments.content: Congratulations Gibbo !! This is a very well chosen location with lots of photograpic opportunities. At risk of hi-jacking Gibbo's thread, it might be worth adding to the earlier information that directions to The Mud Dock can be found here Mud Dock : Caf and that there is plenty of overspill parking on Wapping Road (wonder where they got that name..--img-- ) which is nearby. If you're coming from out of town and don't know the way, it's likely that approaching Bristol via the M32 (which is Bristol's link motorway and is Junction 19 on the M4) is one of the simplest ways in, even if you are coming from the north. At the end of the M32 follow signs towards the SS Great Britain then the Arlnofini if you don't have satnav. If coming by train and arriving at Temple Meads station, if you cross the main road in front of the station (and live...--img-- ) then go to the right, follow the road round to the left by the burned out petrol station (yes, really..) and follow this road, which is called Redcliffe Way, straight ahead, passing the hotel on your left. When you reach the small roundabout by the church (St Mary Redcliffe) go straight across, leaving the small garden to your left. Go down the road which is ahead of you and to the left hand side of the pub and you're there. A brisk walk would take about 10 - 15 minutes. I'm hoping to be there, so if anyone wants my mobile number who hasn't already got it, please PM me. Useful information Robert ! it should prove most helpful --img--  You commented on Wapping Road and where it got its name from. Well I checked it out in a book by Veronica Smith called Street Names of Bristol however unfortunately her research turned up nothing exotic except to say presumably it may have been named after the parish of Wapping in London which was also a dockland area . Veronica was a friend of mine and a well known Bristol historian but unfortunately she passed away several years ago. Best wishes and looking forward to Saturday Mike --img--

interestingcomments.content: I've come across an Android App called Photo Mate that will allow an android tablet to view RAW files. Anyone know if it works with DNG? They mention on their site DNG as one of the formats supported. They also offer a demo version which is free of charge (which they suggest to use in order to find out if your image format is supported). The answer for your other query will take some more time; hopefully, I'll be able to supply the requested information tomorrow. https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.tsgames.pictureinfo&hl=en

interestingcomments.content: Hi, I'm really sorry that no one answered your question. I'm living in Germany near Dusseldorf and made several short trips to the capitals of european countries. Rome is missing.......but too far away....... So be patient.......... Cheers Bernd PS: follow my feet....--img--  The World's Best Photos by deandare06 - Flickr Hive Mind
